output.conclusion: This course provides a solid foundation in analog electronics, equipping you with the knowledge and skills to analyze, design, and troubleshoot analog circuits. Further exploration of advanced topics and practical experimentation are highly recommended.
output.introduction: Welcome to the intermediate-level course on Analog Electronics! This course builds upon basic electrical engineering principles and delves into the analysis and design of analog circuits. We will explore various components, circuit configurations, and their applications.

chapters.description: A quick recap of resistors, capacitors, and inductors. Focus on their behavior in AC and DC circuits, impedance, and reactance.
In-depth look at diode characteristics, including forward voltage, reverse breakdown, and temperature effects. Applications like rectifiers and clippers.
BJT structure, operation, and biasing techniques. Common-emitter, common-collector, and common-base configurations.
JFET and MOSFET structures and operation. Enhancement and depletion modes. Biasing techniques for FETs.
Using small-signal models to analyze transistor amplifier circuits. Gain, input impedance, and output impedance calculations.
Cascading amplifier stages to achieve desired gain and bandwidth. Different coupling techniques (RC, direct, transformer).
Understanding differential amplifier operation, common-mode rejection ratio (CMRR), and applications.
Ideal op-amp characteristics, inverting and non-inverting configurations, and basic op-amp circuits.

chapters.chapterTitle: Op-Amp Applications: Summing and Difference Amplifiers
chapters.description: Using op-amps to build summing amplifiers, difference amplifiers, and instrumentation amplifiers.
Designing integrator and differentiator circuits using op-amps. Limitations and practical considerations.
Introduction to active filters. Low-pass, high-pass, band-pass, and band-stop filter design using op-amps.
Principles of oscillation. Wien bridge oscillator, phase-shift oscillator, and other oscillator circuits.
Linear voltage regulators: series and shunt regulators. IC voltage regulators (e.g., 7805).
Introduction to switching regulators: buck, boost, and buck-boost converters. Advantages and disadvantages.
Class A, Class B, Class AB, and Class C power amplifiers. Efficiency and distortion considerations.
ADC principles, types (flash, successive approximation, sigma-delta), and applications.
DAC principles, types (R-2R ladder, weighted resistor), and applications.
Sources of noise, noise figure, and techniques for minimizing noise in analog circuits.
